overview: Choir 2 is a large choir open to all voice types, focusing on Western choral repertoire, both sacred and secular, from the seventeenth century to the present day.

The subject encourages inexperienced and experienced singers to improve their singing skills, including learning to pronounce texts in different languages. Students develop their vocal technique and an understanding of choral traditions through the experience of singing representative compositions.
Students attend rehearsals working towards a public performance in the final week of semester.
This subject is marked on a pass/fail basis and is not included in the weighted average mark (WAM) calculation.
Students may provisionally enrol via the Student Portal, but places are not guaranteed until students have passed an audition for this subject. The audition can be submitted via Canvas.

This subject is co-taught with MUSI10059 Conservatorium Choir 2, MUSI20083 Conservatorium Choir 2 and MUSI30175 Conservatorium Choir 2. Students cannot simultaneously enrol in co-taught subjects in the same study period.
ilo: show technical development as ensemble musicians;
participate with ability and self-confidence as a team member of a performing group;
perform selected repertoire to concert standard;
identify and exhibit specific knowledge of a range of ensemble repertoire;
exhibit an informed respect for the values and principles of ensemble performance.
generic_skills: demonstrate a capacity to think critically and independently;
study selected repertoire relevant to the ensemble to performance standard;
apply time and people management skills to rehearsal and performance planning;
demonstrate teamwork skills in rehearsal/performance groups.

Prerequisites.content: AUDITION: Students are required to pass an audition for this subject. The audition can be submitted via Canvas.
Students may provisionally enrol via the Student Portal, but places are not guaranteed until the audition is passed. Students will be notified of their audition outcome by email.

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Preparation of parts, individual and/or sectional practice and active participation in all rehearsals.
Three web-based multiple choice tests, based on assigned reading, relevant to the experience of music performance

assessment.hurdle: Active participation in the end of semester performance, dressed in concert black clothing (details provided in Canvas).
Less than 80% attendance will result in a fail. All assessment components must be passed in order to pass the subject

date_times.contact_hours: 31 hours, comprising one 2-hour rehearsal per week, and performances as directed.
